A desk guillotine.

Cut the guillotine out of 3mm wood. To make the blade slide perfectly it has to be sanded. Also you need a short string and two M3 bolts and nuts. Glue everthing together and connect the string to the blade.
Have fun!

title: Drain Catch - 40mm drain with 15 mm center hole

description.text:
Remixed this strainer to fit in my 40mm drain, added a 15mm hole in the middle to allow for my stop plug, then increase the drain hole sizes. Printed upside-down for the best bet adhesion.

Thank you to UrbanAtWork for posting the original design to work off of.

author: capcom

description.text:
This is based on the famous LOVE sculpture by American artist Robert Indiana.  
I drew up individual 1" letters in Alibre CAD using Times New Roman.  Then I made an assembly and exported to stl.  
I have added the CAD assembly source files in both standard STEP format and 3DSystems ASM format.
Print some love.

remixed_from.title: Modular carriage for 40x20 rails (using 3 solid V wheels)

title: Modular carriage for 40x20 rails - tarantula plate

description.text:
I used this as a starting point http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1839201
I integrated tevo tarantula stock hotmount and bltouch bracket to one of the plates.
I did this because with the original design i lost about 40-50mm from the build height, and with this remixed design I gain about 30-40mm compared to the original design of this thing.
Also added a small shelf for a LED strip on the bottom.

comments.text: What probe offsets are you using ?
comments.author: GoatboyHicks

comments.text:
I'm not currently using this as I have completly rebuilt the tarantula to use linear rods for all axes, but if I remember correctly I needed to use a shim from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1534021, i believe i used this one: BLT_STOCKMOUNT_1875SHIM.stl.
And the offset was about 1.95mm, but you need to fine tune it yourself as all printers are uniq
comments.author: GoatboyHicks

I recently bought an AppleTV, but I don't have any shelves near my TV, and I didn't want to add any.  
My TV can either sit on a stand or be mounted on the wall, so with mine on the wall I had an attachment point left unused.  
This bracket screws into that port and grips the AppleTV tightly.  
I tried to make the code reasonable, but I got lazy near the end when putting the screw holes in.

title: Top of Bot Prusa RAMPS Mount

description.text: I could not find any good ways to mount my RAMPS electronics on the top of a Prusa, so I made one.

Print two. You will also need:
6xM3-20
6xM3 nuts The nut traps are intended to be pressure-fit. I pushed nuts into them with a pair of pliers before mounting the clips on my bot. This ensures the nuts do not fall out and get lost in the future. The clips are a tight fit on the frame and cannot be moved left and right, but do allow the RAMPS board to be swung upwards so you can run wires under it. The RAMPS 1.4 board has only three mounting holes; on one clip you will use both holes and on the other clip you will use just one.

title: Function parser for OpenSCAD and parametric curve grapher

description.text:
One of the OpenSCAD limitations is the inability to pass functions to functions or modules.
This library lets you define mathematical functions in a string, using all of the OpenSCAD mathematical operators (and a bit more). This string is then compiled to an optimized representation which can be evaluated fairly quickly. For instance:

use <eval.scad>;
f = "pow(x,3)*y-x*cos(y)+y";
fc = compileFunction(f);
echo(eval(fc, [["x", 12], ["y", -5]]));

will evaluate the function at x=12 and y=-5.

Parsing the string is not fast, but if you evaluate the compiled function for different variable values, the evaluated function should be fairly fast (in my test, about 10,000 eval()s per second).

There are three public functions provided:

  • compileFunction(f): takes a function string f and returns an optimized compiled representation; the representation is described here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2289738
    There may be some bugs in the optimization. If you run into problems, add the optional argument optimize=false.
  • eval(fc, variables): takes a compiled function fc and evaluates it for the specified parameter values; variables is a vector of [variableName, value] pairs; for instance, [["x",1],["y",2]]
  • evaluateFunction(expression, variables): use this to evaluate an uncompiled function once; this is a convenience function equivalent to eval(compileFunction(expression,optimize=false),variables); if you are going to evaluate the function more than a couple of times, please compile it once first, and then call eval() on the compiled version

The string function representations should be able to use all of the following standard OpenSCAD language elements:

+ - * / %  
pow sqrt cos sin tan acos asin atan atan2 abs ceil exp floor ln log round sign
PI
cross norm max min concat
let
?: != == >= <= < > ! && ||

Vectors are supported, using [x,y,z] style vector forming and a[i] indexing.

Numbers can be specified in the usual way, and the true and false constants are available.

Additionally, the ^ infix operator is provided as a shorthand for pow, and COS, SIN, TAN, ACOS, ASIN, ATAN and ATAN2 are provided which are radian-based trigonometric functions.

There are likely multiple bugs I have yet to catch, and there may be some subtle deviations from OpenSCAD order of operations.

The demo file is a 3D parametric curve grapher. You should be able to use the Customizer (unless it times out) to change the formula.

Benchmarks:

On my i5 based Windows 10 laptop, per 10,000 runs with x^3*y-x*y^3:

  • compileFunction() with optimization: 25 seconds
  • compileFunction() without optimization: 21 seconds
  • eval() applied to precompiled function: 0.8 seconds
  • evaluateFunction() 22 seconds

Note: As I update eval.scad, I will upload new versions here. However, I will not be regularly updating the version inside the demo file. There is a repository here:
https://github.com/arpruss/miscellaneous-scad

Update notes:

  • Jan 18, 2018: evaluateFunction(x) works when x is a scalar: it just returns x
  • May 6, 2017: No longer distinguish the "fast" variables x,y,z,t from the others. Remove dollar sign operator for variable values in compiled form now that I've discovered a fast check for whether something is a string.
  • May 16, 2017: Fix evaluator bug in some functions like exp(x) and floor(x).
  • May 17, 2017: compileFunction() and evaluateFunction() should now work if fed in an already-compiled function; in that case, compileFunction() returns its input and evaluateFunction() is the same as eval(); this means that you can seamlessly support compiled and uncompiled function arguments in the same module; I also removed a warning when optimizing a function that uses norm()
  • May 18, 2017: PI supported

title: Garmin Fenix3 Workstand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I own a Garmin Fenix3 and ha a few different watch band straps, steel, leather and rubber. I found it annoying to loosen and tighten the screws without support. It was easy to damage the screws.
The workstand is making the loosening and tightening of the screws easier by aligning the screwdrivers and keeping them in a straight line. In this way the screws will survive tightening/loosening longer.
The rib is low enough so that the workstand could be used when replaceing the crystal or the bezel.
When replacing the watch band its good to know that the dots in the BERGSLÖPARNA logotype indicates the direction of the strap with with a buckle on it. It always confuses me...

title: LED Strip Mount Angle Brackets and Join Plate for use with upper Gantry Printers like the AO-10x, Mendelmax or the TAZ

description.text: Be sure and take a look at the latest version of these lightbars here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1803781 This is a simple re-angle of the existing LED mount clips by Flurin, to allow the LED strip to point down towards the heated bed. It could be used for a side gantry mount as well. The join post allows for two LED strip mounts to be joined for a longer overall strip. You will need the LED strip holders themselves from Flurin's project.

Prints just fine with a .5mm nozzle. You will need 2 of the LED strip mount pieces from Flurin's project as well. The clips are designed to allow you to zip tie the cable to the lighting mounts and then run it through the actual clip piece into the T-slot for cleaner routing. The LED strips just stick directly on. I recommend purchasing the waterproof ones even if you are not worried about water exposure, as they give the final part  amore finished look and only cost a few pennies more.

description.text:
This is a bolt on mod for the FT-5 that will easily allow you to link the two separate Z motors. Parts used are;

  1. 1 760mm GT2 looped belt
  2. 2 GT2 5mm Bore Toothless Idler Pulley
    3 2 GT2 Double Head 20 tooth Timing Belt Pulley

To use this, simple replace the pulleys on the steppers with the double headed replacements, install the smooth pulleys on the block with 5mm bolts, I used a nylock on the top to make sure they never came lose. Use the spare bolts and T Nuts your kit will have to attach the Frame-Mount STL to the front. I believe I used 8mm bolts with wingnuts for the the Frame-Mount to attach it to the block. Works great video can be found in the folgertech Facebook group.

Printer:

FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Only printed with supports on the block as there is a large overhang with slots for the bolts that set position go through

description.text: Use a PET bottle to dispense water in a chicken coop.  I used a 2.25L PET bottle and it roughly supplies enough water for 1 chicken for a week.

Glue the PET Bottle cap into the hole in the top, its a tight fit.  Cut a hole in the cap.  Fit and glue rings to PET bottle to stop it collapsing due to lower pressure in top (bottom) of bottle.  
Use a coat hanger to hold the bottle and hook on to chicken wire.  Use duct tape to secure coat hanger.  
No support required except there is a small bridge section.

description.text:
I designed a new mpcnc based on my own needs (energy chain, mounting points for attachments, modularity for the pipe connectors).

At the moment I have no room in my appartment for such a big toy, but I will build one in the future.

I also created another kind of drive for the x and y axis, which is used in Prusa printers. The belt tension will be placed on the carriages and the stepper motors on the top of the corner posts.

comments.text: Almost anyone can draw on a computer. To make things, to have them work properly are different stories. As for inspiration, better get it from proven design, not computer sketch. Besides this is based on an other machine and you should tell it.
comments.author: maot1985

comments.text: exactly that is the reason why I "draw" it on my own. I know my 3d printer at home and how it is calibrated. Printing proven existing designs can fail, especially when the parts are big. I don't like wasted plastic. I use Inventor from Autodesk. Inventor can not import stl-files, only export, so it is not possible to manipulate existing stl files. Besides, that this machine is a remix is shown on the page.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: So why publish instead of  keeping it as long it is not proven ? People here may be tempted to build it and then ? The majority of projects published here never complete and they hide the very few valid ones.
comments.author: maot1985

comments.text: I give you a quote from thingiverse: "Show us what you made: the world wants to see it! 3D modeling and printing is still in its infancy. The more you share your work, the more your designs inspire others, get printed, and do awesome things." Sure, my project is not printed or built yet, but perhaps there are some points, which could be interesting for others. And I think in comparison with other things on Thingiverse, this thing is quite detailed.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
There is no "unlike" button here. I can and do recognize a good design and I tell it. Here I don't see anything original, innovative and as it doesn't even exist, want to warn people. In fact there plenty of design errors that a working model would show quickly. The comment section is for everyone to read, not to just discuss with the publisher. If you can't take a critic, just publish things that are worth and working.
3D printing is far from infancy, so don't be a kid.

description.text:
For more models and paid version please visit my cult3d profile:

https://cults3d.com/es/usuarios/guaro3d/creaci%C3%B3n

on instagram: @guaro3d

This is a model that I designed a while ago, before having a 3D printer, I have seen some people here that have CNC Router, so maybe they will find it useful.

Is the scale model on the famous America Yatch in 1:200 scale, the pieces are meant to be cut on 1mm plastic or wood sheet. For my model I cut the skeleton on plastic and the deck on 0.5mm balsa wood. Look at the pictures for reference.

I guess you can scale up the model to get other scales (this is really small for adding details)

Greetings, your comments and tips will be much appreciated.

comments.author: FherraZ

comments.text:
wow i like the design and the reprap aspect.But it wasnt easy to find.
why isn´t everyone usingordinary t slot profiles. Sourcing them from Motedis is way cheaper then getting any of those fancy v slot profiles with these extra expensive wheels. And this printer proves it.
I will definetily build this one as my second printer :) sourced and build from scratch.
comments.author: brooti1988

comments.text: Because using T-slot implies you have some other motion system such as linear shafts or linear rails. At lengths over 500mm or so rods deflect too much to be useful, so another motion system must be found. V-wheels on V-slot provide a good cheap way to build the frame and motion system into one. Good linear rails are very expensive.

Look more closely ^^
One of the main design choice here is to use the standard cheap T-slot as the frame AND linear guide, so no need for anything else :)
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: A lot of cheap Chinese printers use V-wheels on T-slot. It ends up being a problem as the wheels contact on one sharp spot and wear out quickly. I know it "works" but it doesn't work long-term. You can use V-slot as frame and linear guide and have a better solution which lasts longer, it costs a little more but I think it's worth it. The D-Bot does this and it works excellently. The argument for size makes no sense, the distance between the wheels is less with V-slot than with T-slot.
comments.author: watsdesign

comments.text: But here we have no wheels at all (hence much more compact), just a printed part gliding on a standard profile :)
comments.author: superjamie

comments.text: Oh I see now. Interesting, a friend has tried this before but didn't have any luck with it. There is also https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2373538 which uses Igus Tribofilament for the D-Bot.
comments.author: watsdesign

comments.text:
That remind me, Igus always made their tests comparing to ABS.

I'm building an H bot using spectra cord instead of belts and wanted to ask two questions. 1) When you did your research, did you find any significant advantage to the H belt configuration when compared to something like the approach used by CoreXY?  2) On your latest sketchup model, you show three extruders spread across your X axis. comments.text: I'm hoping to put up more info on the CoreXY site soon but the main difference between CoreXY and a standard h-bot is that CoreXY is self-stabilizing and the h-bot is not. In an application like FoldaRap where there is a support structure, the awkward routing of the cables is probably not worth it. But in other cases (like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6640)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi..., this feature is an advantage.

description.text:
Lightweight frame for h8 mini mainboard, plug and play mount with bi adhesive tape or rubber band.

I have made four version, two for 6mm and 7mm motors and two dedicated to the fantastic silverixxx firmware!

https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2512604-Eachine-H8-mini-acro-firmware

The silverixxx version have an aperture in the front to allow space for the connectors

This frame are very light and durable, the 6mm weight only 1.82g and the 7mm 2.28, printed in ABS.
The diagonal of 6mm is 80mm and for the 7mm is 90mm.
I have build a 6mm fpv quad with Boldclash F-01 with 16,86g of total weight (without battery)

I hope you enjoy my thing and dont esitate to write comments and tips for further improvement!

title: Malyan M150 X-Carriage for V6 Hotend

description.text:
A lightweight printhead for Malyan M150 or Wanhao I3 (or basically every printer with 45mm distance between the rods) and Drylin bearings.
Accomodates cable chain, endstop and V6 hotend.

Problem: Unless you have a very long inductive sensor, it won´t reach far enough down to actually probe the bed without punching your hotend through... V1.1 is in the making!
Also V1.1 will have 12mm brass bearings. (but i think I will post a version with the regular bearings too).
Pics coming up as soon as I get my camera working again...
Tap the holes for the cable chain and the hotend clip with a M3 tap beforehand to prevent splitting the layers. Screws for the endswitch went in without any further postprocessing.

After thinking about bowden extruders for a while I just bought a cheap V6 hotend clone from China to give it a try. I found some designs for V6 hotends on wanhao printers but was never quiet satisfied by their overall design. As I print mainly in ABS, I don´t need a cooling fan(might change sooner or later...) and I didn´t want to screw many parts together. No more than three parts total was my goal. Also the belt is finally running straight in all directions.
Next to the hotend is a 12mm hole for an inductive bedprobe, but I haven´t had the time to test it.

description.text: Introducing the Rev Mounting Module (AKA the rev sandwich). This is designed to work with the soon to be released Rev expansion hubs. this design is compatible with the Actobotics and Tetrix hole patterns. description.text:
FRANCAIS :

Salut à tous
Voici un model de moteur ~CAT comme cache pour le moteur electrique de notre camion RC echelle 1/14 , model King Hauler fabriqué nous meme en ALU (voir vidéo Youtube)
Si Vous voulez voir le model en action

Paramètre Impression : (comme je l´ai imprimé)

  • Remplissage : 100% ( je n´ai pas testé moins, je débuté encore donc moins aurez surement suffit, mais bon , tout le mode débute ;) )
  • Hauteur de couche : 0.2 mm
  • Support : OUI, conseillé
  • Temps d´impression : 7 heure ~

PS: Les détails que vous voyez sur le coté du cache sur les photos n´est pas inclu dans le model, se sont des reste de mon prototype qu´on a coupé de celi ci pour ensuite les collé sur le vrai model XD

ENGLISH:

Yo,
Here´s my model of a cover for our RC Truck 1/14 scale, it covers up the electric motor.
Both models are with, STL and Solidworks file for modifying ;)
If you want to see how it looks like:

Print Info: (like I made it )

  • Infill 100% (maybe you can choose a lower infill, didn´t test it :) )
  • Layer : 0.2 mm
  • Support : Yes ( highly recommended , but sometimes hard to cut away, did it with a dremel)

author: mc6767

description.text:
This is a simple phone cradle. I designed it specifically for the HTC One M9 Plus, although it should work for any phone of similar size. Note: I made this a bit wider to accommodate my phone's case as well, if you do not have a case, it may be a bit looser fitting.

Can be printed without support standing up, or laying on its side. If printing standing up, some supports for the build plate may be preferable for the small fillets at the bottom, but are not required.

Edit: After printing I realized that this thing might be a bit over engineered in terms of strength. To help remedy this I have removed the back support and replaced it with a small 45 degree support in back. I do not think this will compromise the integrity at all under normal use and it cut the print time down by ~33%.

author: kinka

description.text:
It's super easy to build a contact microphone to "electrify" your instruments. And I mean "instruments" in a very broad sense.

Just get a piezo element. Solder wires to it and connect to an amplifier.

My case is for a 20 mm piezo and is designed to be screwed in place. You can also fasten it with zip ties, Velcro or plain tape.

I use hot-glue to fix the microphone to the case. Try to minimize the amount of bubbles in the glue, since it can distort the sound.

The small tabs on top will hardly print, but is there to make velcro straps or tape stick better.
It's a tight fit so you may need to "fiddle" a bit to get everything in place. Scrape the inside with a knife or small file.

This is the base of a hanging artwork. Do You have two or more things to balance and spin?
Then you could use this OpenScad-file to make a mobile. Example:
Mobile for saving coins.

Use a bottom-up strategy. Start measuring the lowest group of 2 items. Enter their weight m1 and m2 into the scad-file. Check the object's sizes to prevent collision of parts. Then set a length of the base in the scad-file. Print it. Check the balance. Then continue to the upper level. I used an average density of PLA ro=1.320/1000 (gramm/mm^3).
For ABS you can set ro = 1.08 /1000 for light objects (not tested). The Coin Mobile Example: In addition to all printed part you will need the coins and some string.
Print 2x 1EUR frame and 1 x 2EUR frame from
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22901
Insert the coins. Connect the 2x 1EUR frame to the mobile_p1.stl base.
Then connect it to the mobile_p2.stl base. Then connect the 2EUR frame. Done. When finished the assembly I realized coins are obviously not a good choice for fast spinning. The surface/mass ratio is too small. You might place it near a door or a window to get enough air flow. Maybe hot glue some paper wings to each frame! ;-) Any other ideas what to do with foreign currency coins after vacations?
Please show me your ideas of spinning 3D-objects.

comments.author: elspeth

description.text:
This is an updated version of my original TIG electrode grinder.
It is still a work in progress.
There are a few improvements. There is now a slot in the side for cutting off a contaminated electrode.
You should be able to remove the attachment from your dremel without having to remove the diamond disc from the tool.
It should be quite a bit sturdier.

This is currently set up to use a 40mm diamond disc. I can configure it for different discs, I just need to know the diameter and thickness of the disc, the diameter of the arbor and the distance from the top of the threads on the dremel to the bottom of the disc (when it is bottomed out in the collet)

It currently is set up for 1/6", 3/32" & 1/8" electrodes with included angles of 15, 30 & 45 degrees.
I'm open to suggestions for additional angles. I just picked those randomly.

title: MOSFET Mounting Bracket - Wanhao i3, Monoprice Maker Select V2

description.text:
One thing I didn't like about the original bracket was that it put the board at a slight angle. I changed that and also moved the MOSFET further back where there are less wires.

MOSFET wiring info: http://3dprinterwiki.info/wiki/wanhao-duplicator-i3/di3-advanced-mods/heatbed-terminal-burning-fix-with-mosfet-board/

comments.text: Worked well on my Maker Select V2.  The only issue, and I would guess why the original bracket used the further stand-off, is that it causes the mini-usb connector to be slightly mis-aligned.  I was able to crank it down a bit and get it to work.  However, the standoffs would ideally be made slightly lower to accommodate.  I might re-print it as my printer is currently having issues making clean holes / circles, so the print wasn't perfect, but produced a workable part.  Once I figure out how to fix my circle problem, I will probably decrease the standoff height and give it another shot.  Thanks for the part!
comments.author: rsaz904

comments.text: simplify 3d might be the solution to your circle problem.... was causing me lots of trouble in any version of cura I tried. granted some of the tubes I was attempting to print were relatively small, but the difference between the two slicers is like night and day. I am using it more professionally so the cost was justifiable to me, if you're just tinkering it may not be worth it to you. but the improvement in print quality and the method of working is much more effective in my opinion. but i swear i tried everything to fix those circles in cura...

title: Safety "Keyed" Light Switch - Front Slit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit May 7, 2017: I added a photo of a high-resolution (100µ) print of the light switch cover in white. This came off of my FFCP with no sanding or post-print work. High-resolution takes a lot longer, but it's sometimes worth it!

Oh, and if you need a key for this cover, please visit my other Thing, the "Super-Secret High-Security Key":

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2296541

Starting to use LIFX+ infrared lights with my security cameras, and I realized I needed a safe way to stop people from turning the light switch off. I tried the original, but when I used it in a teen's room, he ended up turning it off from the side anyway, saying: "If you didn't want me to turn it off, why did you leave a hole?" Ah ha!

So I decided to re-design something from my childhood: the infamous "keyed light switch" that foiled all but the most ingenious of engineering types. This model has a much larger opening in the front, which accommodates all sorts of household objects but NOT (most) fingers. Whew! Both sides are, obviously, closed off.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed this without supports, although I could see the benefit of using them. I've printed two of these so far, upright, with no supports, and haven't experienced any issues.
You may need to clean up the inside a little after printing. I had a few "strings" inside. Easy to fix with a little sandpaper or tweezers.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

I printed a copy of anthem's "Light Switch Protector" shown here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2010893

I then used digital calipers to figure out the required geometrical objects, their sizes, cut-outs and offsets. I started with a rectangle, extruded, added tapered screw holes, mirrored them. Created an ellipse, projected it various ways, made it larger, and smaller, and extruded, and cut, until I had the raw "full cover" shown below. After adding a few fillets (I love fillets!) to various edges where it made sense, I called it "done" and printed it in black, because that's what I had on the printer. I also had luminous white filament (glow in the dark) but I'm not a fan of permanently-installed glowing things in my house.

I started with Fusion 360 and took it directly into Simplify3D to print. Worked like a charm!

Printed at medium, with a darker color (shows fewer imperfections), these look fine. But if you print them lighter, try to print at a higher quality if you can. description.text:
12.31.17 update: smoothed edges, fixed errors, and added hole for nail or tack. Added skeletonized version.

A scaled down sword stand for your kitchen swords... I mean knives. Might be a little too big for some printers, It had to be printed at an angle on my CR-10. It was designed in blender as a means to replace the knife block which takes up counter space and can not be cleaned on the inside where it is likely filthy. This stand takes up virtually zero counter space so feel free to put a cutting board right in front of it! It's light weight and minimalist. One nail in the top center support should hold it firmly if the bottom is resting on the counter plane. Make sure the tabs of the horizontal supports are inserted as to keep the rear (against the wall side) flush with the vertical stands, it will be a snug fit.

This is a battery compartment which can hold up to four AA and AAA batteries and a SD card. Unfortunately the lid does not fit very well when printed on a Replicator2x. The walls of the lid are not thick enough. I was not able to simply increase wall thickness in AutoCAD. Advice on how to do it is very welcome. This model is a result of an assignment trying to satisfy the following requirements:
  • Hold either 4 AA or 4 AAA batteries
  • Hold a SD card
  • Can be attached to belt or camera bag
  • Protect batteries against splash water

Furthermore you can change height, wall thickness and lengths of the straight parts.

author: nroff

description.text:
2x2 Duplo Head for Ball-joint Adapter

Sure "Base_Duplo.stl" from original is not correct. (A little bit bigger).

use "14.2_Base_Duplo.stl" - its base compile from "duplo_2x2x1.stl"

Origin:

Summary

I present a way for you to create a track base using Lego or Duplo for your Hot Wheels track. These ball-joints allow you to create interesting layouts, bridges on a slant or incredible jumps!

Note: Duplo adapter is untested for correct measurements. Try it if you like, or wait until this notice is removed since it will then be tested to be ok.

I'm working on another tripod base that does not require Legos or Duplos.

Print Settings

Printer:
Wanhao Duplicator 4S

Rafts:
Doesn't Matter

Supports:
No

Resolution:
0.2 mm

Infill:
30%

Notes:
ABS or similar is recommended since PLA will wear out and loose the ability to stick well to the Lego pieces.

I also recommend to print several at once to allow the ball part to cool down enough while printing. I printed 4 connectors at once, which worked well.
